title: kids miss out secondary school places
story: Around , students in England will fail to get their top choice, analysis by the Good Schools Guide suggests.Anxious parents will find out the outcome by letter from this morning, with a shortage of places expected particularly in big cities and a high demand for the best-performing.An estimated , children applied to start a secondary school in September of this year, a rise of , from .A number of factors may lead to a child being prioritised, and can include entrance exam results, eligibility for  benefits and proximity to the school.Bernadette John, director at the Good Schools Guide said: “Secondary school can be key to unlocking a child’s potential, so no wonder parents are dismayed when the place they get is for an undesirable school.“It has been known for a long time that secondary schools would need to accommodate increased pupil numbers but little action seems to have been taken.“In recent years, some local authorities have struggled to find enough places at primary school level and now we have begun to see the impact on secondary schools.”Parents are asked to list between three and six schools in order of preferences when they applied for the places in October .Last year , children missed out on their first choice - a rise from .Ms John warned parents waiting for results today: “For the next few years, it will get worse.”For further advice on appeals, consult the Coram Children’s Legal Centreor gov.uk schools-admissions appealing-a-schools-decisionPaul Whiteman, general secretary of NAHT headteachers union said there was a desperate need for long-term planning that spans all sectors.“Until the Government sorts its act out and comes up with a national strategy to guarantee there are enough school places for every child in England, the annual anxious wait for families will always be a problem, he said.School Standards Minister Nick Gibb said today was a signicant milestone for thousands of parents and children and maintained standards have risen since .

title: benjamin netanyahu corruption israeli prime minister
story: Charges of bribery, fraud and breach of trust are expected to be brought by Israels attorney general in connection with three cases.Mr Netanyahu, who is up for election next month, said in a TV address that the attempt to indict him would collapse like a house of cards.He is accused of accepting luxury gts - including cigars, pink champagne and jewellery worth ,- from Hollywood film producer Arnon Milchan and the Australian billionaire James Packer.Mr Milchans gts were allegedly infor help with a US visa and tax breaks.Both Mr Milchan and Mr Packer denied any wrongdoing and face no charges.But the embattled Israeli PM also faces two more cases linked to charges of fraud and breach of trust after allegedly trying to get more favourable press coverage for himself.More damaging are accusations he struck deals with Israeli media mogul Shaul Elovitch, who owns the countrys largest telecom company Bezeq.Infor positive coverage on an Elovitch-owned news site Mr Netanyahu allegedly made regulatory promises worth hundreds of millions of dollars to the media tycoon.Mr Elovitch, who himself faces a legal battle, strongly denied wrongdoing, however police said their investigation concluded the two men engaged in a bribe-based relationship.The charges are set to be brought by Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit.In a defiant broadcast to the nation the prime minister claimed to be the victim of a left-wing witch-hunt that had been timed to topple him as the election on  April approaches.He said: The left knows it cannot beat us at the polling booth, so for the past three years they have been carrying out an unprecedented witch-hunt which has one aim - to topple the right-wing government which I lead.A final hearing likely to take place after the election will determine whether the charges go forward.Mr Netanyahu and his we have faced similar corruption charges over the past three years.In June last year his spouse Sara Netanyahu was charged with fraud for allegedly misusing ,in public funds to order lavish meals from Israels most famous chefs.US President Donald Trump, a close friend of Mr Netanyahu, offered the Israeli leader a boost ahead of the expected announcement.He said at a press conference yesterday: “I just think he’s been a great prime minister and I don’t know about his dficulty but you tell me something people have been hearing about, but I don’t know about that.“I can say this: that he’s done a great job as prime minister. title: queen picture purple hand official snap
story: The -year-old monarch yesterday hosted King Abdullah, Queen Rania and Crown Prince Hussein of Jordan at Buckingham Palace, and was seen smiling cheerfully for the snap in a ivory white, three-quarter sleeved dress.But sharp-eyed royal fans were concerned to see Her Majestys left hand was a dark purple colour as she co-hosted the event with her daughter, Princess Anne.Tracy Edgar tweeted: Im concerned. Why does she have such a terrible bruise on her left hand  Did I miss something  But as always, she looks stunning!However, Catherine Longstaff suggested this was a normal bruise, writing: The lady is . At that age any little knock unfortunately turns into what can look severe bruises. The Queen is rather fab though isnt she The Queen is generally known to enjoy excellent health.Concerns were last raised over when she pulled out of a morning service at St Pauls Cathedral in June last year, but it later emerged it was due to a cold.Dr Sarah Jarvis, GP and Clinical Director of Patient.info says its common for everyone to get bruises from time to time, usually after an injury, when small blood vessels under the skin break.There are three main reasons older people are more prone to bruising.Firstly, as you get older you lose some of the protective fatty layer under the skin.This protects capillaries from bumps and knocks. The second is that many older people take ‘blood-thinning’ medicines. Aspirin stops your platelets, which clump together when you cut yourself to stop bleeding, from being so sticky.It can dramatically reduce your risk of another heart attack or strokeyou’ve already had one. Anticoagulant medicines are givenyou have an abnormal heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation , to cut your risk of stroke.AF affects over a million people in the UK and gets more common with age. Finally, as you get older you become more prone to falls.On a packed visit Jordanian royals also met Prime Minister Theresa May after attending the Jordan Growth and Opportunity Conference.Mrs May yesterday pledged that the UK would underwrite a £million World Bank loan to Jordan to help it borrow money at a lower rate and manage its national debt.Approached by The Sun Online, Buckingham Palace said they were unable to comment on the matter.

title: mum sold newborn baby for 69 to childless woman she met online
story: Irina Volkova, , a car wash manager from Penza, western Russian, traded the child with a buyer she met online after she decided she did not want to keep the boy, detectives say.The buyer, named only as Anna, , in local media, is married and claimed to be infertile when she concocted the scheme with Volkova, who has two older kids.The pregnant woman travelled from Penza to St Petersburg, which is a -hour car journey, to give birth in Annas home city.Both women are suspected of carrying out a passport scam to fool medics into handing the baby to the buyer.Vladimir Tsurkanu, of the Russian Investigative Committee, told Komsomolskaya Pravda newspaper that the case is a disturbing example of the black market trade in babies.He said: “Similar stories are taking place all around Russia. Police seek to block such attempts.“But women are trying to give birth using someone ’s documents to fool the legal system for adoption.”Police fear that children are also being traded for sex crimes or body parts - although this is not alleged in Volkovas case.She had travelled to St Petersburg , where Anna lives, to give birth to the boy, Mr Tsurkanu said.He said: The pregnant woman tookpassport and was admitted to hospital under the younger woman’s name.“Doctors spotted that the woman and the passport photograph did not match and made a note about it.“Next day after giving birthleft the maternity hospital without the baby.”She handed back the internal passport - used by Russians as an ID document - to Anna who was detained when she went to the hospital to pick up the child.Both women were detained on suspicion of “trading a minor”, said Mr Tsurkanu.He said: “The birth mother was accusedselling her son. She pleaded guilty and repented.“The other woman also gave evidence. So far we have all the proof of the guilt of the women accomplices.”A court said that the baby should be given up for adoption - so neither Volkova nor Anna will raise him.The St Petersburg prosecutor’s office said: “Both accused women face up to ten years in jail.”

title: ex education secretary micheal gove wants to wipe out private schools by making state ones better
story: The Brexiteer, who is now the Environment boss, said he would love to see the day where sending kids to a fee-paying school was seen as the eccentric choice for parents.As it was revealed that record numbers of kids will miss out on their secondary school places today, Mr Gove said independent schools were doing more to help the state sector, but that he would want to drive up standards where.He said in an interview with the Evening Standard: I would have hoped we would have been able to make sending your children to a private school, as it is in Europe, an increasingly eccentric choice.When askedhe wanted to end the independent sector by choice he replied: Well, yes.And he said privilege in education was a fundamental inequality in society and there was so much that was wrong about it.Back in  he famously rallied against Eton.The key thing is: are children from disadvantaged backgrounds and children from non-privileged backgrounds getting a fair chance  he added.Labour want to strip schools of their charitable status to try and balance our the inequality.Mr Gove set out a string of reforms to the education system when he was in the Department from May  until July , some of which enraged parents.And he joked today that he regularly argued with his kids about making GCSEs harder - because his daughter is now sitting the same exams.He said they were very cross with him over it but he had no regrets.In the same interview he suggested that Brits were more relaxed about sky-high immigration now because we would take control of the numbers after Brexit.Yesterdays figures showed another drop in the number of Europeans coming to study but a -year high in net immigration from outside the EU.Now that people know that we have democratic control, actually there’s been a greater degree of acceptance of migration overall, he said.And he even admitted that he didnt ever think Leave would win the referendum back in  - but he was glad the result was Brexit.

title: madeleine mccann cops ask home office for more money
story: The Home Office today received an official request from Scotland Yard to extend funding for Operation Grange - the investigation into her disappearance - until March .So far, £.million has been spent on the investigation after Madeleine vanished on holiday in the Algarve, Portugal, on May , .Parents Gerry and Kate left their three children – including toddler twins Sean and Amelie – sleeping in their apartment while they dined at a tapas bar -  metres away.When Kate ed to check on the kids at around pm that evening, she discovered that Maddie was not in her bed and was missing.And politan Police detectives are now hoping the extra finding will help them more closer to finding Madeleine, who would have turned  on on May , .In April , UK cops released a computer generated image of Maddie showing what she would look like aged nine.A number of potential leads have emerged since the little girl vanished, but none amounted to anything and no arrests have ever been made.There have been more than , potential sightings of the Brit three-year-old since her disappearance, but police have so far failed to locate her.Kate and and Gerry previously said they are extremely thankful to both the Home Office and Scotland Yard for the continued funding.

title: spot the pea puzzle bamboozles the internet but can you find it
story: Among the nutritious peas, broccoli, sweetcorn and beans, lurks one particular pod housing two identical green peas.But they’re so well hidden you could find yourself pushed to the VEG of despair trying to uncover them.The brainteaser was created by Birds Eye to mark its involvement with Veg Power and ITV’s Eat Them to Defeat Them campaign which aims to inspire children to eat more healthily and help tackle rising childhood obesity levels.A spokesman said: “We are so used to seeing our peas already out of their pods that some people won’t even realise they aren’t grown as they appear on our plate.That will make this puzzle all the more dficult as you try to search for the two peas sat together in their pod.Sweet and tender peas, which are a great source of vitamin C and protein, are picked from their pods at the perfect time so hold their nutritional value when frozen and even count as one of your five-a-day.As we mark Pea Week, using the Eat Them to Defeat Them campaign, we hope to get kids on our side by helping us to defeat the peas – by eating them.

title: labour remainers bribe may to help pass brexit deal but only if they get peoples vote
story: Jeremy Corbyn could get behind a plan to allow Brexit to happentheres a promise of another vote later on to confirm or reject it.The Labour bosss own plan for a soft Brexit was thrown out by title: us vow to seize brexit opportunity with bumper uk trade deal in boost to economy
story: Negotiators laid out their stall yesterday for what they want to see in a trade deal with Britain after we leave the EU.But farmers warned that any agreement must not allow food to be imported with lower standards than we have now, which could put their businesses at risk.The Office of the United States Trade Representative, led by Robert Lighthizer, put out an -page list of demands of what title: theresa may admits she may have to delay brexit even if her deal passes
story: According to diplomats, the PM told Council boss Donald Tusk she would have to seek a short, technical prolongation of Brexit talks no matter what.Michel Barnier told a meeting of EU ambassadors yesterday there has been no new progress in the talks due to UK demands over the backstop.He said Britain was still insisting on a time limit or unilateral exit clause, despite Brussels repeatedly rejecting those solutions.The Frenchman also told Member States that the UK has not tabled any new proposals at a flurry of technical talks over recent weeks.An EU diplomat told The Sun: For the time being, we can’t see a new angle from the Brits so theres no substantial progress.There has still been no paper provided by the UK.An EU official warned: They cant take the Commission by surprise by coming with a text on the last day.Ambassadors were also told that Mrs May admitted for the first time a short Article  extension will be required evenMPs vote for her deal.Meanwhile it was also reported today that Michel Barnier has told EU ambassadors that there has been no progress on Brexit.Mrs May is still trying to win concessions from the bloc to get her MPs to back her deal when it comes back to the Commons this month.The PM met with Mr Tusk in Sharm El-Sheikh on Sunday, where the pair agreed to work up new legal assurances on the backstop before the meaningful vote.The diplomat said: Looking at the necessary legislative procedures in the UK, it seems more and more inevitable to extend eventhe deal goes through on the th.”The official added: If everything goes to Plan A well probably end up with some kind of short extension that will of course by approved by the Council.

story: One of the PM’s frontbench team sent a bombshell note to a breakaway MP saying: “Well done for what you are doing – we agree with everything.”And a string of Labour MPs have sent supportive texts to members of The Independent Groupas they contemplate signing up.The explosive revelations come after Chuka Umunna finally emerged as the group’s new leader as the  formally took up their parliamentary roles.It will fuel rumours more Tory and Labour MPs could tear up their membership cards and sign up to the new group.Shockwaves were sent through Westminster last week when eight Labour MPs and three Tories quit to form the new TIG group.And they have been in talks with peers and councillors across the UK to urge them to defect.A source close to the group said many Labour MPs are fed up and believe Labour has become a Corbyn “cult” – but are too terried to quit.They said: “They are bloody frightened – the abuse, the threats. story: NewsBigamist caught after relative tells first we about invite to second weddingStephen Ainscough, , invited  people to his second wedding bash in Wigan, Greater Manchester, despite still being married to his first we SandraShareCommentsByBarnaby Kellaway:,  MAR NewsThe -year-old smiles as he poses with his new we Angela "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA bus driver who was still wedded to his estranged we when he tied the knot with another woman has been spared jail.Stephen Ainscough, , organised a full-on wedding bash with up to  people when he married his new bride Angela Atkinson.This came despite him still being married to his first we, Sandra, from whom he had separated after  years of marriage in . There were no discussions about making their separation official before Mrs Ainscough heard about her exs upcoming wedding from a family member in .  She received a orce petition in the post not long after and agreed to the terms, it was heard. The pair attended Wigan Family Court in December , two months after Ainscoughs marriage to Ms Atkinson. Mrs Ainscough says she questioned him about the incident and was told the event in October was just a ceremony and not a marriage. They ed to the family court a month later and Ainscough said he wanted to marry in  months so his father, who was in poor health, could attend. The hearing was adjourned and Mrs Ainscough became suspicious, so she contacted the vicar of a Pemberton church and was told a wedding had been conducted. In a statement read out to the court she said she was absolutely shocked and quite upset.  Nick Lloyd, defending, said orce proceedings started before any plans were made for the wedding. His client did not know there had been a delay, he added. Mr Lloyd said it was an extremely unusual offence to come before the courts and the number of cases nationally each year was in single figures. Ms Atkinson, who attended court with Ainscough, remains with her husband and they hope to have a smaller wedding later in the year. title: brian reade holiday delay paradise
story: NewsopinionBrian Reade: My holiday delay in paradise cooked up a British comedy classicGetting stuck in another country at the end of a holiday is the ultimate nightmare – but being trapped with other Brits can be grimly fascinatingShareCommentsByBrian Reade:,  MAR NewsopinionIf there is an upside to travel delay nightmares alongside fellow Brits, its the comedy that happens all around you "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIve never had much sympathy for holidaymakers stuck in exotic locations after their flights back to Blighty were cancelled. What’s not to love about a couple of free extra days by a hotel pool while the sun is shining  I thought. Until it happened to me and my family this week, after Thomas Cook twice cancelled flights from Cancun while we were at the airport, leaving us delayed for  hours. Because with your head already checked out, your clothes stinking and information blackouts worse than Theresa May’s on Brexit, it was about as much fun as being locked in the gold-plated bathroom of Philip Green’s Med-sailing yacht watching him take a thrice-daily dump. But there was a silver lining. A chance to observe Brits abroad at their most stereotypical and realise that we probably survived the Blitz due to the quality of the comedy that adversity brings out. There’s the Smug Silver Surfers, with no jobs to worry about, who whooped when they heard they were being put up in a five-star hotel, told everyone  to chill as they grabbed another GT and bragged that the compo cheque would pay for another tan-tastic break.   The Faceless Corporate B*****ds Who Are Nowhere To Be Seen, shydragging out of bed a couple of uninformed reps to placate a -strong mob armed with only a smile, a shrug and a phone to wave as they say “as soon as I hear anything, you will”. The Bawling Self-Righteous Resistance, treating the female reps like collaborators who’ve slept with the Nazis, who claim to know exactly what’s happening and why Thomas Cook won’t tell us. As in “I used to deliver parts to engineering firms and I can tell you for a fact the part this plane’s waiting on won’t get here ’til next week.” The middle-aged man in the replica football shirt accosting random yellow-bibbed airport workers and demanding to know what’s going on, only to be told “Que  I am cleaner”. Who then walks back to his we, shaking his head in disgust and shouting: “Pedro over there hasn’t got a bloody clue. Typical.” There’s the Angry Teacher who thinks he’s in charge of a school trip who shouts down the pilot as he addresses us: “You’re feeding us misinformation. This is just like Kafka.”   Which draws puzzled looks from certain bystanders who think: “Ooh, Kafka sounds worse than Thomas Cook. I won’t be travelling with them.” Your daughter’s on shyFacebook telling schoolmates “THIS IS LIVING HELL”, while your son posts pictures back to shyworkmates of him by a swim-up pool bar with a glass of draft Corona saying: “The sheer agony of a plane delay.” Your partner head-butts her phone as she rows with a Twitter feed ironically called Thomas Cook Cares. Which is essentially a faceless non-pacier , miles away spewing: “Hi, sorry to hear about that but we have no updates on that issue.” There’s the Benny Hill-like chases through the hotel concourse when rumours spread that we’re about to be freed, followed by Last Plane Out of Saigon scenes as shaking mothers throw children and luggage on to coaches. And the realisation that this will soon be a distant memory but,you’re ever stuck for cash, what a doddle it would be to write a follow-up to Benidorm.

story: NewsBrits fed up with mud bath music festivals now opting for yoga and spa retreatsAge of standing around watching bands in a field may be over as younger generation craves relaxation, activities and a hint of luxuryShareCommentsByAlice Hughes:,  MAR NewsMud was once a major feature of the festival but Brits are no longer keen to get their wellies dirty "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMusic-loving millennials are giving mud the thumbs down – and instead want spa treatments, ski lodges and yoga at festivals. A poll of , festival-goers revealed the tradition of a festival in a field watching band after band is no longer what people want. According to the results, seven in  want activities to get involved with rather than just music to listen to. Popular pastimes Brits want to see on offer at festivals include dining out experiences and local tours, suggesting they’re after more of an overall holiday experience. Cosmin Sarbu, head of Admiral Travel Insurance, whose Ski Festivals Finder tool can help Brits find their perfect festival in the snow, said: “While a lot of people go to a festival to see their favourite bands, many also go for the atmosphere, a new location and other activities to take part in. “It’s important for festival goers – particularly those choosing their first festival – to find the right one for them to fully enjoy the experience.   “For an event which lasts on average a few days, there’s a lot of planning beforehand such as how to get to the festival, what to wear, and how much to budget.” The study also found tying in with the decline in the desire for classic field festivals, one in  are bucking the trend for summer festivals and would prefer a winter event now. It also emerged attendees would like to learn skills when not watching bands, such as playing an instrument, cooking and even skiing. And six in  said the perfect festival includes a mix of activities in the day and parties into the night. The most important factor when choosing from the endless choice of open air music events is the line-up, closely followed by cost and location.   Expectations have changed, as other top factors when deciding on a particular festival were revealed to be the uniqueness of the experience and the key theme. And far from the traditional tent, a hotel was named the ideal place to sleep, closely followed by a log cabin. In fact, three quarters would prefer a festival with a comfortable bed to go back to at night, with the average festival goer considering .am as the perfect time for their head to hit their pillow. But it also emerged rain, litter and insects are among the aspects Brits don’t want to see. Brits polled via OnePoll said the perfect festival will last four days and have no temporary toilets in sight.  While music festivals are clearly the most popular, with three quarters having been to one, other festival favourites include literature, skiing and food. The majority of Brits appear to be home birds, with  per cent choosing the UK for their perfect festival, followed by America and Spain. Cosmin added: “Festivals are no longer just for music – there’s huge ersity in festival types, from skiing and comedy events to food and literature festivals. “All this choice makes it even more important to make sure you’re heading to the right festival for you – location, atmosphere, cost and activities on offer are all part of the experience. “That’s why we’ve created the Ski Festival Finder, to allow people to filter for their preferences and find the best winter festival to suit them. title: david lammys right stacey dooley
story: NewsopinionStacey Dooley-style poverty porn should be axed - show us the truth about AfricaThe Labour MP has slammed the Strictly winner for acting like a "white saviour" in her recent Instagram postsShareCommentsByEva Simpson:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsopinionStacey has been to Africa for Comic Relief"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShack with corrugated iron roof, tick. Impoverished, braless women dancing and clapping in a circle, tick. Nervous looking child in dirty, torn clothes balanced on your hip, tick. Well done Stacey Dooley , you’ve managed to tick every Poverty Porn clicheacute in the book on your trip to Uganda for Comic Relief. I have no doubt the Strictly Come Dancing champion meant well with her Instagram snaps in which she breathlessly tells us she’s “OB.SESSSSSSSSSSED” with the nameless little boy she’s clutching while wearing designer clothes. CRINGE!   But David Lammy is right, it’s both patronising and condescending to the people they’re trying to help and I’m glad he’s called her out for acting like a “white saviour” who’s perpetuating “tired and unhelpful stereotypes”. Comic Relief has a huge  and privilege and it’s the first major way children learn about Africa,” he said. “If they only show Africans as helpless victims to be pitied, children missed the broader picture of huge progress in Africa.” How can anyone disagree with this  Dooley weakly hit back at the politician saying: “You could always go there and try to raise awareness ”   In fact he’s been asked but he said no because he was didn’t want to become “part of a PR exercise”. Instead of launching an attack on Lammy, Dooley and Comic Relief should listen to what he has to say. Like David, I too feel deeply uncomfortable with this tired negative narrative that portrays Africa as a nation of starving, helpless people waiting for white people to come and save their lives. Throwing money at men, women and children is not to only way to help. For example, Comic Relief could save thousands of pounds on travel expensesthey used local camera crews, producers and editors.   This way they would be giving jobs to people to provide for themselves and their families. As someone who regularly goes to Ghana, west Africa, I can tell you the pictures of starving children covered in flies and living on rubbish dumps are not one that I see. In fact that’s one of the reasons AfroBeats artist Fuse ODG turned down Bob Geldof’s request to take part in the Band Aid  – he was frustrated with how negatively the lyrics portrayed Africa. I see a country undergoing rapid transition, incredible growth and one with a very bright future. If you’re planning a holiday, I can’t recommend it highly enough. Sometimes I think it has more going for it that Brexit Britain right now. While Comic Relief has done an amazing job in raising money and awareness it needs to change the record we need to hear more balanced stories about Africa, which, by the way is a continent, not a one country. Can we at least get that right

story: NewsGirl, , diagnosed with oian cancer as parents make desperate pleaDoctors though McKenna "Kenni" Shea Xydias was suffering from a large gas build-up in her bowel, but a scan revealed a tumour the size of a grapefruitShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news us-news video heart-breaking-clip-shows-brave-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA girl aged just two has been diagnosed with incredibly rare oian cancer after stunned doctors discovered a mass of tumours in her abdomen. It was thought McKenna Kenni Shea Xydias was suffering from a large gas build-up in her bowel after her stomach bloated and she came down with a C fever. Her concerned parents, Meagan and Mike, took her to see a paediatrician on February  and were left devastated when an MRI scan later revealed metastasised tumours, including as big as a grapefruit. With Kenni undergoing surgery and intensive chemotherapy to battle stage  yolk sac oian cancer, her devastated mum and dad have issued a desperate plea, saying: This poor baby needs your prayers.   Kenni, from the US city of Senoia, Georgia, is believed to be the youngest person in the US with this form of cancer, which targets the oian yolk sac. It normally affects girls and women aged between  and . She has since undergone surgery to remove most of the main tumour and her right oy. After going to the doctor with worrying symptoms, Kenni was taken to a doctor who ordered a scan, which revealed a tumour measuring cmand a number of smaller ones in her abdomen.   She underwent her first surgery on February , allowing doctors to remove  per cent of the main tumour and some of the smaller cancerous ones. Surgeons were able to save one oy but had to take some small intestines, according to a GuFundMe page, which so far has raised ,in financial support for the family. They hope chemotherapy treatments, which began on Wednesday, will help her to beat the disease. The GoFundMe page, launched by a family friend,states: McKenna Shea is a rambunctious two year old who has never let anything stop her, and never will!  It adds: Meagan and Mike are both educators who just recently started new jobs in dferent counties in Georgia, bought a house, and moved. Kenni also had two amazing older brothers which makes this family of five a little tight on finances. I hope that raising this money will help to ease their worries as they will be taking time off and be without income. Anything will help, including prayers. God has this all planned out, lets do our part.  After the youngsters latest round of chemo on Thursday, an update read: [Kenni] was a bit more sluggish and just happy to hang around and colour. She slept through her chemo treatment for the day. We went for a walk later this evening and made sure she got her exercise in. Other than that, K has been in a great mood acting her silly, goofy, spunky self - and we couldnt be more thankful for that!  The family added: We want to thank everyone for their continued love, support, and prayers. Thank you also for your donations as we continue to prepare for unpaid leave throughout treatment and medical expenses that we cant even comprehend at this point. Thank you for the Smile Grams, letters, and care packages as well. The caring and selflessness that we have encountered on this journey continues to astound us.  Please continue to pray for Kenni, for those who have shared in our comments their own battles against cancer, and for the children we have encountered who are fighting for their lives. Kennis parents have met with fertility doctors to discuss her ability to have children herself in the future. Mike wrote on the fundraising page: Having to consider how these tumours and consequential chemo will potentially effect Kenni in the long run, forces us to look at the big picture as well. Earlier, he told ABCs Good Morning America he had no idea a girl of such a young age could be affected by oian cancer. He said: I know Meagan and I both agree that Kenni is our hero with how shes dealing with this. She is a ball of energy and a stereotypical two-year-old. Shes the youngest child, where she is the boss and shes extremely stubborn, which a great character trait in going to fight cancer. She doesnt let anything stop her.

Maria Gonzalez Roesch and her newlywed husband were on the Royal Caribbean cruise holiday on February  when they literally missed the boat. The Symphony of the Seas ship was docked at Nassau port, and passengers had been given an all-aboard time of .pm. At .pm, the gangway was removed and doors were closed – the couple arrived five minutes later. Footage of the couple running desperately for the ship was then shared across the world.  The video, taken from the neighbouring Norwegian Bliss cruise liner, shows them arrive, run to the front of the ship and converse with workers onboard, who presumably told them it was too late. The clip shows the pair waving their arms in hopes the ship would stop, and desperate screams of “No!” can be heard from as the vessel moves away. After three minutes, the ship starts blaring its departure horn signalling a final goodbye to the port — and the helpless couple are left behind. Maria, , explained on her Instagram that the cruise on the trip had always left at .pm but that day the ship left earlier.   The honeymooning couple had been given a new itinerary but didnt read it and assumed - wrongly - that the ship would leave on the same schedule as at other ports. Maria also claimed they were not the only passengers stranded at Nassau with six others also making the same mistake. The incident occurred on the sixth day of a seven-day cruise and from Nassau, the ship was ing to Miami, Florida.

title: mum sold newborn baby 205
story: NewsMum sold newborn baby for £ to childless woman she met onlineIrina Volkova admitted herself to hospital using the identication of her -year-old accomplice to try and fool the authoritiesShareCommentsByWill Stewart:,  MAR NewsAnna from St Petersburg who agreed to buy the baby for the equivalent of £ "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo women face up to ten years in jail after a mother “sold her newborn baby for pound”. A carwash manager named as Irina Volkova, , who has two older children, decided she did not want to keep her third baby, according to claims by local law enforcement. She is accused of selling the boy to a married woman called Anna, , who believed she could not have her own children. The women are suspected of a passport scam to fool medics into handing the baby to the buyer. The case is is seen as the tip of the iceberg of a disturbing black market trade in babies in Russia.   The women met online and concocted a scheme by which Anna pretended to be the biological mother, said Vladimir Tsurkanu, of the Russian Investigative Committee, which probes serious crime, cited by Komsomolskaya Pravda newspaper. He warned: “Similar stories are taking place all around Russia. Police seek to block such attempts. “But women are trying to give birth using someone ’s documents to fool the legal system for adoption.”   There are fears that children can also be traded by for sex crimes or body parts. Irina went from her home city Penza to give birth in St Petersburg where Anna lives, he said. “The pregnant woman tookpassport and was admitted to hospital under the younger woman’s name. “Doctors spotted that the woman and the passport photograph did not match and made a note about it. “Next day after giving birthleft the maternity hospital without the baby.”   She handed back the internal passport - used by Russians as an ID document - to Anna who was detained when she went to the hospital to pick up the child. Both women were detained on suspicion of “trading a minor”, said Tsurkanu. “The birth mother was accused to selling her son.   “She pleaded guilty and repented. The other woman also gave evidence. “So far we have all the proof of the guilt of the women accomplices.” A court instructed that the baby should be given up for adoption - so neither Irina nor Anna will raise him. The St Petersburg prosecutor’s office said: “Both accused women face up to ten years in jail.”

story: Air traffic controllers in Dundee are to strike because they don#t earn the same as their counterparts in London.The trade union Prospect has notied Highlands and Islands Airports Ltdof its intention to strike, following a ballot where staff voted #overwhelmingly# in favour of industrial action.Prospect has indicated the action could take place on days between April  and August .HIAL managing director Inglis Lyon says the decision #will impact services# at Inverness, Sumburgh, Kirkwall, Wick John O‘Groats, Stornoway, Benbecula and Dundee airports.The dispute involves a claim from the trade union for a double-digit wage increase in   or a long-term commitment to above inflation pay awards.More recently, Prospect has called for air traffic controllers in the Highlands and Islands and Dundee to have parity with controllers at London airports including Heathrow and Gatwick.Mr Lyon said in a statement: #We do not believe comparisons with staff in London control towers are germane, because the volume of traffic experienced, type of air traffic control practiced and cost of living in the South East of England are not comparable with HIAL airports.#As a government sponsored agency, HIAL must follow the Scottish Government pay policy.#Last year HIAL awarded up to three per cent, plus incremental progression, or a one per cent non-consolidated payment to those on the maximum of their grade, to all HIAL staff. HIAL cannot implement pay awards more than that directed by government#This will impact our air traffic services. In the event that strike action cannot be avoided, the airports mentioned above will close for the period of the strike and we will work closely with our airline customers to minimise the impact before and after any action.#Please accept our sincerest apologies for the undoubted inconvenience this will cause and we will keep you updated on our efforts to resolve the dispute.#

title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Friday  Mar  : PM

He attended Millburn Academy before moving to Inverness College two years ago to study engineering."He also worked at the bakery at Marks and Spencer for two years and loved his motocross biking and cars.ldquoSamuel was a happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly.ldquoSamuel was the youngest of four siblings and words canrsquot express how much he will be missed by his parents Heather and Lenny, his brother David and twin sisters Samantha and Kirsty, his nephew Reuben and niece Georgie.ldquoWe would like to thank the incredible number of people who have sent us messages of sympathy ndash your kind words mean so much and are a reminder of just how popular and well-loved Samuel was."We hope he will always be remembered this way.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Historic Inverness city centre mosaics almost completed
story: FINAL measurements have been taken for the re-installation of a well-known Inverness mosaic.Restoration work to breathe le into the historic mosaics in Invernessrsquos Academy Street started in July last year.It came after Cairngorm Taverns secured an Inver-ness Townscape Heritage grant to fully restore the former AI Welders building, which is set to have a street-level bar and first-floor restaurant.It appointed conservation specialist Laing Traditional Masonryas its main contractor although the first phase of work has been handled by sub-contractor the Mosaic Restoration Company .The mosaic of welders and foundry men at work was partially taken down last year by Northamptonshire-based MRC. Mosaics have been taken to MRCrsquos factory for restoration ndash and as one of the four original mosaics was missing, the firm has used a photograph from the s to recreate the original design.MRCrsquos Gary Bricknell described it as a fascinating project for the family-run firm and he looks forward to putting the work back in place next month.ldquoItrsquos been an really interesting job, he said. ldquoEvery one of the tiles is hand-cut for these arches which are about four or five square metres. Wersquove used tens of thousands of tiles and wersquove been working on it for over six months now.Inverness Townscape Heritage Project provided a pound, grant towards the restoration of the B-listed building which is set to open in September as a showcase for Cairngorm and Loch Ness breweries.Sam Fairclf, managing director at Cairngorm Brewery which is involved with Cairngorm Taverns, said: ldquoWe are looking to showcase as much Highland produce as possible.The building was originally the head office of the Rose Street Foundry and Engineering Company and changed to AI Welders in the s.This project is the first major investment by the Inverness Townscape Heritage Project, which is a partnership regeneration project focusing on Academy Street.The refurbishment is a collaboration of funding partners including Inverness City Heritage Trust , Historic Environment Scotland and the Heritage Lottery Fund.Alison Tanner of ICHT said: ldquoThis is not just an interesting project, it is specialist restoration, repair and reinstatement work and needs to be rejoiced.ldquoIt has been years in the planning, the local public are passionate about the mosaics and the building as a whole and this work will save them for future generations.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Hotel plan for Inverness car park site
story: PLANS which would see a city centre car park transformed into a six-storey hotel have been unveiled.The pound million proposal by developer SRP Inverness Ltd was displayed to the public at the Spectrum Centre on Farraline Park, immediately next to the two-deck Rose Street car park which is earmarked as the site for the -metre high hotel.The proposal is the latest city hotel development from SRP Inverness directors Stewart Campbell and Stuart McCaffer, who were also behind the creation of the Inverness Encore Hotel, now the Pentahotel, on nearby Academy Street.Mr Campbell is confident the -bedroom L-shaped building will attract interest from a globally-known hotel brand, bringing something new to the Inverness accommodation mix.ldquoWe have worked with a number of global brands over the years, he said.ldquoInverness has massive global tourism and a lot of people, particularly global travellers, want the comfort of a well-known global brand.ldquoInverness is a strong tourism market, but therersquos been a lack of supply over the years. Other than the Travelodge on Academy Street in , there hasnrsquot been a new hotel built in Inverness since .The proposal includes a gym, three retail units within the hotel footprint and parking for  cars.Mr Campbell believes the hotel will benefit from its proximity to Inverness bus and railway stations, while any under capacity at the car park would be compensated by the nearby multi-storey car park.Mr Campbell and Mr McCaffer also own the neighbouring Rose Street Hall, which they hope to utilise for retail or restaurant use once the hotel is completed.Between the two, they also plan to construct a new bus and taxi road, replacing the footpath linking the bus station and Rose Street retail units.SRP Inverness expects to apply for planning permission in mid-April.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Inverness College students showcase work of Highland Hospice
story: DRAMA students at Inverness College UHI have teamed up with Highland Hospice to offer insight into the patient experience of palliative care.Third year BAdrama and performance students performed Homeward Bound, a -minute play charting one couplersquos experience of end-of-le care, after being approached by the hospice.Officials at the hospice were keen to see live drama used as an educational tool to help improve the quality of palliative care and the experience of those involved.The play was performed to staff and nursing and care students at the college, with hospice representatives providing commentary to provide context and insight into the experience.It proved such a useful educational tool, the drama students have been asked to perform the play again at the NHS Highland Highland Hospice Essentials in Palliative Care Conference at Eden Court in Inverness, on March -, where it will be filmed to be used in learning.Lesley Mickel, programme leader for the drama course, said: ldquoWe were delighted to work with Highland Hospice to develop this special performance, which really highlights the human impact of late diagnosis and the importance of quality palliative care.ldquoIt was not only a challenge for our students in terms of portraying these very raw, human emotions, it also proved an extremely useful educational tool for students studying other parts of the university curriculum, with our nursing and care students gaining a much greater understanding of the issues involved.Hospice learning and development practice lead Siobhan Neylon said: ldquoIt was such an honour to work with these wonderful students on this poignant and emotive drama.ldquoThey portrayed the characters in such a dignied way.Homeward Bound was written by playwright Brian Daniels and tells the true story of Lesley and her husband Seth Goodburn, who was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer at the age of . He died just  days after diagnosis.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Inverness MP calls for cross party approach to secure post Brexit funding
story: INVERNESS MP Drew Hendry has issued a cross-party rally cry ahead of Brexit.He has written to the Scotland spokespeople of each of the main political parties urging them to put pressure on the UK government to prevent Scotland losing out on millions of pounds in EU funding,the UK leaves the EU.Mr Hendry, the SNPs business spokeman, has called on parties to work together to ensure the UK government delivers a like-for-like replacement for vital EU development funds in the event of Brexit.Mr Hendry said: ldquoCommunities across Scotland would be hit hard by the loss of millions of pounds in vital EU fundingthe UK government drags us out of the EU against our will."The best way to protect this funding is for Scotland to remain in the EU - as we voted overwhelmingly for - butBrexit does go ahead then the UK government must commit to replacing every single penny of the funding Scotland stands to lose."It is shocking that the UK government has already broken its own word, and failed to consult on detailed plans to replace the lost EU funding and the huge benefits it brings for Scotland.ldquoIn addition to the many other benefits of our EU membership, Scotland has enjoyed huge investment in jobs, communities and infrastructure from European funds. It is vital that this investment continues like-for-like, and that the Scottish Government continues to oversee the funding so it meets Scotlands needs.ldquoAt present, groups across the country need to make decision about their future, but have no idea what sort of funding will be available after . This must not be another power grab away from the Scottish Parliament.ldquoSome of this funding helps level the playing field of regional inequality, which is stark when comparing rural areas with urban parts. The Tories must be held to account, investment levels must be matched, and clarity must be given to communities across Scotland.ldquoThe UK government cannot continue to kick this issue into the long grass and weasel out of their responsibilities. It is time for MPs and MSPs of all parties to demand that this money is protected in full and in time to give certainty to communities across Scotland."Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Inverness pupils donate money to city cycling charity
story: PUPILS at an Inverness secondary school have selected a charity which provides cycle outings for the elderly to receive pound in funding from the Young Philanthropy Initiative .The scheme is sponsored by the Aberdeen-based Wood Foundation and students in each school were asked to make presentations to fellow students and a  of judges who selected the winning team which had a chosen charity.Millburn Academy have donated their money to Cycling Without Age, Inverness ndash a charity with specially adapted bikes which takes residents from care homes and Highland Hospice on rides around the town and local countryside.Alice Munro, principal teacher of English, said the competition was a great experience for the pupils.ldquoThey invited people from ious charities to the school and went out to see the work these charities do in the local community. After their research, teams were asked to give a presentation and the judges were former staff members, the school chaplain and a police representative.ldquoThe winning charity, Cycling Without Age, is a fantastic organisation doing great work with the elderly in the community.Cycling Without Age spokesman Mick Heath said: ldquoIt began as an idea in the head of Dr Katie Walter of Cairn Medical Practice.ldquoShe recruited me to be her helper. It all began with a chance encounter in July .ldquoWe started networking and soon had a grant from HiTrans Active Travel to buy our first electric trike for taking the elderly and frail out for rides.ldquoWe were quickly joined by Dr Moira Finlayson and we three have been going at it flat out since then.The charity now has four trikes and several volunteer pilots and has taken more than  passengers on more than  rides.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Opinion divided on how to tackle Inverness gull menace
story: TIDY streets could be a more effective deterrent to Invernessrsquos seagull menace than culling, according to the RSPB.The suggestion comes in response to a call for a limited cull by city businessman Charlie Barbour.Mr Barbour, who owns city centre bars The White House and The Dog House as well as commercial property agency Barbour Commercial, suggests that destroying a small number of nesting pairs would make the centre of Inverness more attractive, safer and quieter.Describing the birds as ldquonoisy, dirty, aggressive and a blight on the city centre, Mr Barbour questions whether the Inverness Business Improvement Districtpolicy of removing eggs each year is enough to permanently reduce the gull population.ldquoWhilst a cull of such birds is not a universally popular decision, I just wonderthere is merit in destroying say three or four nesting pairs of seagulls each year, he writes.ldquoA reduction in seagull numbers would improve the city centre experience for visitors and that surely has to be a good thing However, a spokeswoman for conservation charity the RSPB said that lethal control should only ever be a last resort, used only where there is a proven problem and other alternatives have proven ineffective. Instead, local authorities, businesses and iniduals should tackle the problem by reducing the birdsrsquo food supply by cutting down the amount of edible litter and introducing gull-proof litter bins.Other non-lethal options include putting up physical barriers such as netting on roofs as a deterrent before the breeding season.ldquoWe believe that gull problems in an urban environment are best tackled by reducing the availability of food and nest sites. If the features that attract gulls remain, any `vacanciesrsquo created by controlling existing gulls will simply be filled by other gulls moving in, she said.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Rethink on Inverness city centre revamp
story: COUNCIL officers are to go back to the drawing board amid concerns over an ambitious project which aims to transform a key area in Inverness city centre.A bold vision including wider pavements and reduced traffic speeds in Academy Street was unveiled in November at the start of a public consultation.The Accessing Inverness project aims to complement a pound million upgrade of the rail station plus a revamp of the Victorian Market and involves HiTrans, the regional transport partnership for the Highlands and Islands, Highland Council and other organisations.Although the project team wants to apply for Sustrans funding to take the project to the next stage, Inverness councillors have demanded further work, including an impact an assessment for people with disabilities.It follows concerns that removing light and sound-controlled pedestrian crossings plus making the street and pavements the same level will pose dangers to visually impaired people.Inverness Ness-side councillor Ron MacWilliam described the design and report presented to councillors as ldquoflawed and said something had to happen.ldquoNumber one is making sure people who are least able to navigate their way around the streets of Inverness are considered in any design, he said.ldquoI donrsquot think people who are blind or partially-sighted have been considered.Accessing Inverness team leader Fiona McInally stressed there was more work to be done but the deadline for the funding application was April .She said the proposed design was outline only.ldquoIt is not set in stone, she said. ldquoWe are trying to get to a position we can get a solution and go forward.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said people had been asking for improvements for years and there was now an opportunity which must not be missed.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Ski slope plan for ex quarry outside Inverness
story: Inverness Snowsports Centrehas been told by Highland Council that it does not require an environmental impact assessmentat this stage for the proposed development at Torvean on the A Loch Ness road.ISC was formed by a group of snowsports and mountain bike enthusiasts who believe Inverness should have a venue for such activities for all ages and abilities.Project manager Helen Morgan said they envisage all-year-round attractions including mountain biking, zip wires, high rope trails and downhill tubing, all based around a snowsports core. It is estimated a pound million to pound million investment is required.The plan includes a building for catering, changing and hire of equipment, plusrooms available for rent.Panoramic viewing areas will be provided from where the sporting activities can be observed in comfort.The council has been told there will be ldquonegligible noise or light pollution as most of the development would be below the top rim of the quarry. There will be some removal of scrub trees and gorse and brambles, but mature trees will not be felled.The area is a Site of Special Scientic Interest as it is formed by an esker, an unusual geological feature where a long ridge of gravel and other sediment has been deposited by meltwater from a retreating glacier or ice sheet. It is one of the reasons gravel extraction was halted back in the s.The area is now used by dog walkers, ramblers, motorbike scramblers and X off-road fans.Inverness Snowsports Centre has launched an online Just Giving plea to raise pound, to pay for the studies required to support a formal planning application.Keen skier Miss Morgansaid they wanted to ensure people of all abilities had access to the activities.Cllr Bill Boyd, Inverness West, said: ldquoThis plan sounds quite exciting, but I hope they can come up with funding because the council is not in a position to fund it at the moment.ldquoIt could be an ideal centre for local people, schools and visitors.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Success sees Inverness Town House tours extended
story: POPULARITY has prompted the number of guided tours of Inverness Town House to double this summer.City councillors have agreed to add two more tours each week after positive feedback.The tours were introduced in June in a move which completed a so-called cultural triangle which includes the cityrsquos museum and Inverness Castle Viewpoint.Two tours on Thursdays have been run by High Le Highlandand proved logistically and financially viable ndash making a pound. profit ndash with the additional two tours on Tuesdays starting on from May .Tours have not disrupted any business in the building and visitors have found them engaging, informative and entertaining.Inverness provost Helen Carmichael said: ldquoWell done to High Le Highland and in particular their team of guides, who helped the council create a third, new, visitor attraction in the town house, which along with the museum and art gallery and castle viewpoint have created an accessible lsquocultural trianglersquo around the Castle Wynd area.ldquoAs we move towards the redevelopment of Inverness Castle as a new lsquomust-seersquo visitor attraction, the Town House Tours will complement the tourism offering in this city centre location.HLH chief executive Ian Murray said: ldquoHigh Le Highland has been delighted to work with the council to create public access to the splendid town house and we look forward to seeing visitor numbers and tour provision increasing this summer.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: mcinnes cant put finger on why aberdeen have been so poor at pittodrie
story: Dons boss Derek McInnes admits he cannot pin-point why the form at Pittodrie has been so poor in recent months.A shock - loss to relegation-battling Hamilton was the latest setback on home soil for the Reds.Aberdeen have taken just two points from the last  at Pittodrie.They also drew - in the Scottish Cup with Stenhousemuir, the team bottom of League One.McInnes said: “The last couple of games I have tried to give some rationale and reasoning for not being so convincing at home.“There have been some tough games here and maybe also some straightforward ones we would have dealt with in the past.“I can’t put my finger on it.“Teams come up here with a game plan and that is no dference to what it has been. In the last six years teams have come up here with the same tactic to frustrate.“There have been dferent games, dferent systems we have come up against.“While we are getting plaudits for some of our away form you cannot achieve what you want in any seasonyour home form isn’t good.”Following the injury exit of Max Lowe against Hamilton, McInnes took on Mikey Devlin and went to three centre-backs.He said: “Their front two caused my centre-halves problems so we went with three main headers when Max came off injured and matched up.“Systems, changes and things like that are there to test you as they are part of the game.“But for me, that wasn’t why we lost the game.“We never really looked settled defensively.“We were negligent in their box with chances.“We didn’t take enough responsibility in their box and the two goals we lost were avoidable.”

title: aberdeen charity charlie house launches new partnership with teca
story: An Aberdeen children#s charity has announced a two-year partnership with a major new concert venue.Charlie House, which supports children and young people with complex disabilities and le- limiting conditions, has secured a deal with state-of-the-art The Event Complex Aberdeen .A vital link for the city charity, it will also see the exhibition centre create a dedicated changing place for families with children with complex disabilities.TECA, which will replace the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centre , is on track to open in summer this year at its new location in Bucksburn.Susan Crighton, director of fundraising at Charlie House, said: “We are thrilled to announce this key partnership for   and very much look forward to working with the team. Our corporate partnerships are vital to enable us to continue to deliver and expand our services to support families both in Aberdeen City and Shire and the wider north-east of Scotland.”Charlie House launches £ million appeal to build specialist care centre for north-east children" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news local charlie-house-launches--million-appeal-to-build-specialist-care-centre-for-north-east-children embed # secretMttFeRTBR" data-secret"MttFeRTBR" width"" "" title"#Charlie House launches £ million appeal to build specialist care centre for north-east children# # Evening Express" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Louise Stewart, the arena’s head of entertainment, sales and marketing, said: “The new venue is set to make concert attendance much more accessible for the families who are supported by Charlie House with a specic changing place being installed, which is essential to enable the families to spend extended time away from home.“We are also thrilled to continue to be part of Attitude is Everything, which improves deaf and disabled people’s access to live music by working in partnership with audiences, artists and the music industry to implement a charter of best practice across the UK, while we work towards achieving our gold standard.”The charity is currently raising £ million to build the first specialist support centre in the north-east.

Maybe that has something to do with the enormity of what needs to be done.Once again our hospital beds, services for vulnerable people and other things taken for granted will be in the spotlight.The impact on staff was raised, quite rightly, at the IJB meeting, but there was no mention of the impact on patients and service users.As one NHS staff member at the meeting said: #We can bring forward savings, but what we bring back to the board might not feel very palatable.#There is a need for members of the public to have their say in changes to these public services, and a meeting in Lochgilpheadnext week will be discussing that subject.

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the title: honours even for red star in argyll derby

The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowA new film will tell the tale of Scotland#s national drink # the legendary water of le.Scotch: The Golden Dram, a revealing feature documentary on how whisky became the spirit of choice around the globe, is set for UK release on March .The film, by Parkland Entertainment and Munro Films, will have its European premiere at the Glasgow Film Festival on March .Shot on location among the stunning Scottish countryside, Scotch: The Golden Dram tells the story of uisge-beatha, Gaelic for #water of le#, which is enjoyed in more than  countries, generating more than  billion in exports each year.The film charts the Cinderella tale of legendary master distiller Jim McEwan, a veteran with more than  years standing in the industry, who takes on the dilapidated Bruichladdich distillery on his home island of Islay and turns it into an award-winning blend.Some of the other ardent enthusiasts featured include Richard Paterson, a master blender whose nose was insured for . million, as well as biochemist whisky-maker Dr Bill Lumsden, and master distiller Ian MacMillan.The film marks director-producer Andrew Peat’s feature- documentary debut, a passion project for the American filmmaker who studied at St Andrew’s University.Andrew Peat said: #The heart of our film is the characters, the men and women who produce Scotch whisky, from the barley farmers to the bottle makers. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby
