title: cousins-team-up-to-help-paddle-boarder-near-dunbar
story: Emergency services were called out on Saturday afternoon following reports of a paddle boarder in dficulty near Thorntonloch.Both Dunbarrsquos RNLI and Coastguard teams were involved, alongside North Coastguard Rescue Team and Civil Nuclear Constabulary.The callout marked the first time that Alan Blair, an RNLI volunteer for nearly  years, had been on a call-out alongside his cousin, -year-old Lewis Blair, who joined the Coastguard in January.UK Coastguard paged for the inshoreand all-weatherleboats at .pm after a member of the public raised the alarm.The crews launched minutes later and both boats were on scene by about .pm to begin a search.The person was spotted on rocks near Thorntonloch Beach before it was established the casualty had managed to make their own way to the shore.The paddle boarder, who had got into dficulties after being blown away from shore, did not require medical treatment.An RNLI spokesman said: ldquoStand-up paddle boarding is fun in flat water or surf and can be enjoyed by the whole family but this incident highlighted the potential risks.

title: children-settling-into-life-at-new-wallyford-primary-school
story: They celebrated their first day in the building last Wednesday.Mhairi Stratton, headteacher, said: "Irsquove been really impressed at how quickly the children have settled into their new school."Theyrsquore enjoying the outdoor space and the freedom it gives them."The more open classroom layouts area also great and very flexible for learning and play."They absolutely love the dining hall ndash itrsquos a really nice space. The whole environment is really relaxed.Parents also enjoyed tours of the school later the same day from pm to pm so they could familiarise themselves with its layout.The size and scale of new house building in the area meant that the former school at Salters Road was no longer able to meet the needs of the community.Land was secured on the east side of the town as part of the St Clementrsquos Wells development to create a new campus to offer room for modern educational facilities for a growing school population, surrounded by plenty of outdoor space.East Lothian Councilrsquos development partner, Hub South East, was responsible for delivering the project and appointed Morrison Construction as the contractor.The project received a pound.m grant from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Scotlandrsquos Schools for the Future programme.

title: parking-time-limit-restrictions-at-musselburghs-old-town-hall-tightened-up
story: A new Traffic Regulation Orderwas introduced on Monday. Although the location had been subject to a -minute limit in the past, the council created additional spaces to which the time restriction needed to be enforced.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoThe previous TRO made reference to the size and shape of the old road layout and therefore couldnrsquot be enforced following the construction of the new road layout.She said that a -minute waiting restriction would remain from St Peterrsquos Church, past Loretto School.The spokeswoman added that parking issues with motorists leaving their vehicles all day were compounded following the removal of Police Scotlandrsquos traffic warden service in  as there was little chance that vehicles would be ticketed.The council was then granted powers on January , , to carry out parking enforcement and undertook a series of reviews on town centre parking.A new parking layout, including additional spaces and new parking for bicycles has since been introduced by the Town Hall.The spokeswoman said: ldquoThe restrictions were  minutes before but had been ignored as no enforcement could be carried out.ldquoThe council then got enforcement powers and a Traffic Regulation Order has brought in -minute limited waiting within the new road layout near Musselburgh Town Hall and on the section of High Street opposite.ldquoThe disabled parking spaces will also be enforced, ensuring blue badge holders can park close to a busy town centre.ldquoThe -minute restrictions will create a turnover of vehicles and stop all-day parking, which should assist the needs of businesses, visitors and residents during peak times. These timed restrictions will operate between the times of .am to .pm, Monday to Saturday.ldquoThe issue of increased car ownership is a major contribution to the parking problems found in Musselburgh and in other towns throughout East Lothian and, whilst this is a dficult problem to address, the council is committed to tackling such issues by improving the quality of transport infrastructure across East Lothian, promotion of sustainable transport options and identying opportunities to create more car parking spaces such as the new parking provision in Musselburgh High Street.ldquoIn addition the councilrsquos parking strategy includes extending and introducing residents parking schemes throughout East Lothian.

title: politicians-disappointed-with-apology-letter-from-scotrail
story: Martin Whitfield MP and Iain Gray MSP had written a letter to ScotRail in January outlining the problems that East Lothian constituents were facing after complaints of late trains and too few carriages.ScotRail responded by saying: ldquoWe know that train performance hasnrsquot been good enough in recent months and I am sorry for how that has impacted our customers.ldquoWhen the railway doesnrsquot work as it should, it causes immense inconvenience and disruption for those who rely on us to get to work, or to see family and friends.ldquoThe level of cancellation has reduced steadily over the past month and we will continue to cut cancellations to improve the service.ldquoAs more staff are trained, our performance is improving, and our most recent performance results continue to show an improvement.Both Parliamentarians have branded this letter ldquodisappointing, with Mr Gray saying: ldquoEast Lothian rail users are rightly fed up with ScotRailrsquos litany of excuses and hollow apologies for their ongoing service failures.ldquoActions always speak louder than words. I will not let up in highlighting the problems experienced by constituents and demanding change until we see sustained improvements in the way ScotRail delivers local services.Mr Whitfield added: ldquoOnce again, ScotRailrsquos reply to our service challenge says all the right things about delivering more staff and investing in new and upgraded trains to improve performance.ldquoThe problem is that we have heard it all before, but things never seem to get better.

title: fresh-bid-for-houses-new-clubhouse-and-course-at-dunbar-golf-club
story: Between  and  new houses could be built on two sites next to the -hole golf course, as well as a new clubhouse, a new nine-hole course and practice facilities.The proposals come  years after the club applied to East Lothian Council to develop a new clubhouse, nine-hole golf course, golf academy and driving range, short practice facilities, greenkeepersrsquo shed, housing and hotel to complement the existing course.In October , the scheme was given the green light.Now, a fresh application has been made by Dunbar Golf Club and CALA Management Ltd.The majority of the homes would be built around the existing Deer Park Cemetery, to the south-east of much of the existing golf course.A smaller number of houses is earmarked for land at the current clubhouse, off Golf House Road.Plans suggest that the nine-hole course would be created opposite the housing development being built off Bowmont Terrace.New documents lodged with the councilrsquos planning department, referencing the previously approved plans, state: ldquoThis permission also included a Section  legal agreement which seeks to control the timing of the delivery of new homes alongside the delivery of the new clubhouse and associated facilities, commits the golf club to contributions towards education provision, as well as a commitment to a collaborative approach in promoting the site for a future hotel development [and as per the masterplan].ldquoAs Dunbar Golf Club undertook further work, including marketing the site under the terms of the planning permission, it became clear that the layout proposed in the masterplan accompanying the planning permission in outline did not reflect the best option for future development, mostly with regards to the proposed mix of housing and the balance of the quantum of development between the clubhouse site and Deer Park. Clear feedback highlighted that more units should be proposed at Deer Park, with a limited development of larger homes on the existing clubhouse site.ldquoIn detailed discussions with East Lothian Council, it was agreed that fresh planning permission would be required. Given the size of the site and scale of development, it is considered a major development and therefore triggered the requirement for this formal pre-application consultation process.A public exhibition is to take place on April  at the Dunmuir Hotel, -pm, to reveal the new plans to the public for the first time.The number of houses planned are estimated to be between  and , compared to  in the previous application. The golf club will also maintain a site for potential future hotel development. Councillors Norman Hampshire, Paul McLennan and Sue Kempson, who represent the town, will also be made aware of the plans, as will the townrsquos community council.Dunbar Golf Clubrsquos East Links has played host to many national and several international championships, as well as being a final qualying course for the Open when it is played at Muirfield. The club was founded in .

title: musselburgh-woman-taking-her-dog-to-debut-at-crufts
story: Lorraine Murtagh, , of the townrsquos Delta Drive, and dog Inca are part of the Scottish team competing in the rally competition at Crufts.Rally, the latest dog sport to be recognised by the Kennel Club, involves the dog and handler working as a team to navigate a course featuring  to  exercises.Each course is dferent and there are more than  exercises in rally, including stationary tasks, recalls, jumps, retrieves and cone weaves.Lorraine is entered at level two in the Inter-regional Rally Competition, one of six competitors in the Scottish team at the NEC in Birmingham event next Thursday .The Inter-regional Rally Competition at Crufts features seven teams: Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and four English regions. Last year, the Scottish team finished third.Lorraine got involved in rally just six months ago, having enjoyed other dog sports, and focused Inca is also proving a natural with her love for learning new things.Lorraine, who has five dogs ndash three springer spaniels and two Border collies ndash runs her own dog-walking business, Waggy Walks Edinburgh.She said: ldquoInca is a five-year-old English springer spaniel whom I rescued at just over a year old. I got her from the Dog Aid Society.ldquoShe is the sweetest, most affectionate dog and, at home, loves nothing more than cuddling on the sofa.ldquoOn walks she loves to run and explore, and is always up for an adventure. Inca also loves to work and will turn her paw to anything I ask of her.ldquoShe is always happy to learn and, although we are both new to rally, we are really enjoying learning new skills together. Inca and I also train and compete regularly in flyball and in agility, where she currently competes at Grade . We also do a little Canicrossto keep us busy.ldquoInca is a joy to work with and a wonderful friend.ldquoI am really excited about my first time competing at Crufts ndash I canrsquot wait.Tom Mather, Crufts chairman, said: ldquoCrufts offers something for everyone and this year looks like being no exception.ldquoVisitors to the show will be able to see dogs and their handlers taking part in a iety of activities and displays and we would urge anyone looking to buy a puppy to visit the ever-popular Discover Dogs area where they will be able to meet the breeds up close.ldquoWe feel honoured to welcome dogs from a wider iety of breeds than ever before, representing all corners of the globe.ldquoThe fact that people travel far and wide to enter this prestigious event proves that it really is the worldrsquos greatest dog show.Crufts runs from March  to . Nearly , dogs will compete for best in show, including , dogs from overseas. Italy has the most entries from overseas with  dogs followed closely by France .For more information, visit crufts.org.uk

title: more-than-30-jobs-to-be-created-as-dunbar-asda-extension-approved
story: The extension, which will be to the north of the existing building, is expected to see the store stock more homeware products and also see the launch of a home shopping service.The supermarket giant submitted plans to East Lothian Council before Christmas. Now planners have given the scheme the green light, with no objections from the public.A spokesman for Asda told the Courier: ldquoWersquore delighted with the outcome.ldquoThese plans represent a signicant investment into our Dunbar store and will improve the range of goods on offer and help bring Asdarsquos famously low prices to more people, as well as providing new job opportunities.It is not yet known when work will start on extending the Spott Road store or how long the construction work will take. Currently, the store, which opened about  years ago, has a floorspace of about ,m, with the extension adding a further m to the building.A total of  parking spaces will be lost but it is felt that the remaining  spaces will be adequate because the increase in home deliveries will likely offset the reduction in customer trips to the store.The home delivery service will see four vans operating from the store.One van is expected to make four deliveries per day, with the remaining three doing half that number.Dunbar Community Council backed the plans, while Dunbar Tradesrsquo Associationhad reservations but vowed to keep working to ensure the success of the townrsquos High Street.The planning officerrsquos report noted: ldquoThe proposed extension would sit comfortably on the side of the existing building and would not harmfully disrupt its architectural form and appearance.ldquoIt would be physically and visually well contained to the side of the existing building and would not be an overdevelopment of it.ldquoThe proposed extension would be a subservient and complimentary addition to the existing building and would not appear intrusive or incongruous in its setting.

title: in-pictures-our-lady-of-loretto-youth-players-back-to-the-80s-show
story: The cast of young performers, aged  to , were delighted with the support from audiences over the three days of the recent production.Hit songs by a range of stars from the s ran through the show, which told the story of Corey Palmer, played by Peter Lally, remembering his last year in high school.The music included Footloose, Irsquom Gonna Be , Girls Just Want To Have Fun, Hey Mickey, Shot Through The Heart, Video Killed The Radio Star, Kids In America, The Final Countdown, Total Eclipse Of The Heart and Walking On Sunshine.The -strong cast included: Tfany Houston, played by Kirsteen Brownlee Mr Stevie Cocker ndash Georgio Michalakis Ms Sheena Brannigan ndash Anna Scott Cyndi Gibson ndash Jorgey Scott-Learmonth Fergal McFerrin ndash Jamie Fleming Michael Feldman ndash Luke Davidson and Eileen Brannigan ndash Eva Hills.Jill Alexander, an audience member, took to Facebook to praise the show, saying: ldquoWent to this show on a girlsrsquo night out with no expectations. Was totally blown away by this young grouprsquos talent, enthusiasm and professionalism. What a fabulous group with a shed-load of stars. title: pakistan-hands-over-captured-pilot-to-india
story: Officials brought the pilot, identied as Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman, to the border crossing with India at Wagah and handed him back.On the Indian side of the border, officials greeted the pilot who was in a dark blue suit, accompanied by a representative of the International Committee of the Red Cross.Islamabad has said that the handover was a gesture of peace that could defuse tensions and avoid another war between India and Pakistan.Mr Varthaman was shot down on Wednesday in the Pakistani-held area of Kashmir.His handover took several hours as a roster of procedures were completed including a medical check-up to very his health and condition before being handed over to his countrymen.In a video message aired on Pakistani television channels, Mr Varthaman was seen in his green flight suit saying he was rescued by two Pakistani military personnel when he ejected and found himself in Pakistani controlled Kashmir surrounded by a small mob of seemingly angry residents.It was not clear when he recorded this statement, but it was clearly while he was in the custody of the Pakistan military.On the Indian side of the border, policemen and military personnel greeted Mr Varthaman who was dressed in civilian clothes, wearing a blue blazer and grey dress pants.Earlier in the day, the road on the Indian side of the border was lined with well-wishers. But by the time Mr Varthaman crossed at around pm local time, most people had dispersed.The handover came against the backdrop of blistering cross-border attacks across the disputed Himalayan region of Kashmir that continued for a fourth straight day, even as the two nuclear-armed neighbours sought to defuse their most serious confrontation in two decades.Tens of thousands of Indian and Pakistani soldiers face off along the Kashmir boundary known as the Line of Control, in one of the worldrsquos most volatile regions.Tensions have been running high since Indian aircraft crossed into Pakistan on Tuesday carrying out what India called a pre-emptive strike against militants blamed for a February  suicide bombing in Indian-controlled Kashmir that killed  Indian troops.Pakistan retaliated, shooting down two Indian aircraft on Wednesday and capturing the pilot.Since the escalation, world leaders have scrambled to head off an all-out war on the Asian subcontinent.President Donald Trump in Hanoi on Thursday said he had been involved in seeking to de-escalate the conflict.Imran Khan, the Pakistani prime minister, told politicians on Thursday, ldquoWe are releasing the Indian pilot as a goodwill gesture tomorrow.As a true statesman, Prime Minister of Pakistan Imran Khan announced that #Pakistan will release Indian Air Force Pilot Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman tomorrow as a peace gesture. pic nIbdszkmdash Govt of PakistanFebruary , But India made it clear that the latest escalation has changed its strategy and that going forward, it will strike, including inside Pakistan,they receive intelligence of an attack in the planning.Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi earlier on Thursday warned ldquoIndiarsquos enemies are conspiring to create instability in the country through terror attacks.Also on Friday, Pakistanrsquos civil aviation authority partially re-opened the countryrsquos airspace, allowing travel to four major cities, another sign tensions were de-escalating.The agency issued a statement saying all domestic and international flights will be allowed to and from the cities of Karachi, Islamabad, Peshawar and Quetta.It said other airports, including the one located in the eastern city of Lahore that borders India, will remain closed until March .

title: uk-leaving-eu-without-a-deal-unlikely-says-irish-pm
story: Leo Varadkar was speaking in Belfast after meeting Northern Irelandrsquos business leaders for discussions which he described as being about Brexit and developing stronger economic links across the border.His government is currently making preparations for a no-deal Brexit, but he told media that he believes there will either be a deal or an extension to the negotiations.The Taoiseach said: ldquoWe are entering quite a sensitive period over the next week or two in the run-up to the next set of votes in the House of Commons on March  and the European Council summit which happens the week after.ldquoI donrsquot want to say too much about it at this stage but I think that the United Kingdom crashing out of the European Union without a deal on March  is unlikely.ldquoI think that we either will have a deal or we will have an extension but as is always the case, we have to work hard to achieve that withdrawal agreement, to get it ratied and also prepare for the worst-case scenario in case that arises.Referring to the Conservative Partyrsquos confidence and supply deal with the Democratic Unionists, Mr Varadkar said he feels it has created a ldquonew dynamic in politics.ldquoMy view as the head of the Irish government is that we should try to be honest brokers and be impartial when it comes to dealing with the dferent political parties in Northern Ireland, to work with everyone and also to listen to all sides, he said.ldquoI think that the fact the DUP confidence and supply deal has created a new dynamic, whether it is true or not, some people certainly perceive that it means that the British Government listens more to the DUP than to other parties.ldquoWe see for example that Fianna Fail has decided to create a similar partnership with the SDLP which could create a similar dynamic were they to re-enter government south of the border.ldquoMy view is that we should try to speak to all parties, be an honest broker, but I particularly want to reach out to the centre ground, people in politics and not in politics who share a vision as to how we can work together, put the past behind us and build a much better future.Mr Varadkar ruled out running Fine Gael candidates in Northern Ireland.ldquoNo, no, we wonrsquot be doing that. Not in the foreseeable future, he said.Later, speaking at a gathering of the Alliance Party in Belfast, Mr Varadkar expressed concern that Brexit has weakened Northern Irelandrsquos Good Friday Agreement.He said: ldquoI am deeply concerned at how Brexit has already weakened the agreement and I am concerned that anything that creates new dferences ndash ergence between Britain and Ireland ndash will undermine it more.ldquoWe cannot allow that to happen.

title: no-need-for-checkpoints-on-irish-border-arlene-foster
story: Mrs Foster also reiterated her partyrsquos concerns over the Brexit Withdrawal Agreement, saying it ldquowill not work.Speaking to DUP members and supporters in Mid Ulster on Friday evening, title: glasgow-school-one-of-the-last-private-girls-secondaries-in-scotland-to-close
story: Craigholme School, on the South Side, will shut its doors in August after being unable to resolve financial dficulties.Last year, the school joined forces with Kelvinside Academy, in the West End, in a bid to survive, but under a formal merger the school will now close in August.All pupils will be transferred to Kelvinside to complete their secondary education, although the fate of staff is more uncertain.Read more of todays top Glasgow storiesTeachers may face redundancies unless new positions can be found at Kelvinside.The primary school at Craigholme, which accepts both boys and girls, will remain open as a feeder school for Kelvinside.The closure comes at a dficult time for private schools with steadily falling pupil rolls across the sector following the financial crash of .Since then fees have risen by more than  per cent, with the average annual cost to families climbing from some pound, to its current figure of around pound,. Fees at Craigholme topped pound, a year.The closure also marks another blow for single sex education in Scotland. There are now only four private girlsrsquo secondary schools left and one in the state sector.Craigholme hit the headlines in  when it emerged former pupil Aqsa Mahmood had dropped out of university to join Islamic State in Syria, where she was believed to have married an ISIS fighter.Read more of todays top Glasgow storiesDonald Wilson, chair of the board of governors at Kelvinside Academy and Craigholme School, said the closure of the senior school would now follow the merger.Mr Wilson confirmed pupil numbers at Craigholme had dropped signicantly in recent years, while the impending impact of the Barclay Review, which will see removal of business rates relief, and other financial pressures, presented signicant challenges to all independent schools in Scotland.It has not yet been decided whether the facilities and land owned by the school will be sold off or retained for use by Kelvinside.Craigholme was founded in  by Jessie Murdoch as Pollokshields Ladiesrsquo School. title: Iain Macwhirter  Get over it - cis women are just on the wrong side of history
story: This, apparently, is to educate heteronormative women about their ldquoprivilege ndash the fact that they can use the toilets, sorry ldquowashrooms, of their choice and access healthcare. Irsquom not sure who exactly has been preventing transgender women using public conveniences. So far as I know, you donrsquot have to show a birth certicate, or undergo a medical exam to have a pee. But what do I know as a pale, stale male.What I do know is that ldquocis-gender is an ugly neologism which many women find offensive. They are content with their present sexual terminology. ldquoCis is in the same linguistic ballpark as ldquoTERF ndash trans exclusionary radical feminist, which is a term of abuse used against women who believe persons with penises are, er, male. I should be careful here because a number of TERFS have been banned from social media for saying that a person with a penis is a man. So I wonrsquot say that.Instead, letrsquos just take it as read that in future we are going to have to accept that the concept of sexual dferentiation with which we have been living for thousands of years is finally being exposed as a malign transphobic hood. At any rate, the Scottish Government appears determined to press ahead with reform of the Gender Recognition Act, which will allow trans people to assign themselves legally and biologically female. Hitherto, trans people have had to undergo medical examination and get a diagnosis of ldquogender dysphoria. No more. From now on, anyone can change their birth certicate to whatever they wish.Earlier this month, Holyroodrsquos culture committee warned that ending binary ldquoMale or Female questions in the Scottish census will render much of the results meaningless and, willy nilly, import an unscientic definition of sex into the law. But the Scottish Government is not listening. Nicola Sturgeon told a UN equalities conference last week that the concerns of feminists about the GRA are ldquomisplaced.Women ndash sorry, ldquomenstruators ndash who say that self-ID erases their sexual identity will be told: just get over it. They can complain that ldquosex is a protected characteristic under the  Equalities Act, and that women therefore have a right to their own unique spaces. But now that men can actually become women under the law, this right will be impossible to articulate. Trans women with male anatomy will be entitled to enter womenrsquos changing rooms, girl guide troops or womenrsquos prisons. Women who complain will be guilty of transphobia, and are likely to be visited by the police recording a ldquohate incident.Now, I have nothing against adults changing their gender, or identying as women, queer, non-binary, intersex or whatever. It seems to be reinforcing outmoded concepts of gender to suggest that, because someone wants to wear dresses, play with dolls and put on makeup, they must have a lady brain in a male body. I thought we had left pink-for-girls gender stereotyping behind. But never mind. No-one wishes trans people any ill ndash certainly not me. But now that we are abandoning the very biological definition of sex, there are some anomalies that need to be addressed.Last week, a British transgender man, who had IVF by sperm donation and gave birth, won a court battle to prevent his child having ldquomother on its birth certicate. It will be the first child in history to have no mother. The The AIRE Centre, a human rights charity, contested this on the grounds that it would make le dficult for the child in future, when they apply for visas or anything which enquires about family background. The Government said simply that this isnrsquot a problem. From now on, fathers can give birth ndash end of.But Irsquom not sure this is the end of the matter. Children have not been included in the gender recognition debate thus far, even though they have rights too. It could be psychologically disturbing for a child to find, one day, that its mother has decided to become its dad. That song ldquoSometimes I feel like a motherless child takes on a whole new meaning.Of course, the trans parent will still be present, but is it OK to expect a child to suddenly start calling her natural mother her father  I would have thought that a child has a continuing right to a legal motherthey were born with one. If misgendering a trans person is unacceptable, surely demothering a child should be too. This is going to be confusing to say the least.Then there is the question of sport. The controversy over athlete Caster Semenya, a woman with high testosterone, raises the question of how to regard trans womenrsquos participation in women-only sport. Athletes who have testes, and therefore posses greater body mass, muscle strength and bone density, have an unfair advantage over old-fashioned women who have genetically female bodies.Next week, the International Association of Athletics Federations will argue in a hearing in Switzerland that people like Semenya should take testosterone-suppressing drugs before competing. Not only would this drive a coach and horses through the anti-doping protocols, it surely poses problem for transgender athletes who, of course, also take drugs like testosterone to help them transition to their ldquocorrect male sex. I hope the sporting authorities can get their heads around that because I canrsquot.Yet this is a very live issue in many sports. In the US, the ban on trans women taking part in power-lting events is being lted to prevent accusations of discrimination. You might have thought that having beefy, male-bodied women participating in these contests is discriminating against women athletes. Though, of course, only transphobes would say that, so we wonrsquot go there.The logical solution to this conundrum is to end sexual segregation in sport. Andwomen who are born biologically female never win any medals, tough. Strangely, there doesnrsquot seem to be the same issue about female-bodied trans men participating in male-only sport . Irsquom sure that has nothing whatever to do with the fact that they wonrsquot win anything.So welcome to the brave new world of post-sexual dferentiation, where men become women and fathers have children. It is one of the most radical and abrupt cultural changes in human history.Women have had a pretty bad deal in previous centuries, when they were regarded often as chattels without rights. In some Muslim societies theyrsquore still second-class citizens. Now, as women are finally emerging from the shadow of patriarchy, they are being told, by men, that they no longer have exclusive rights to their sexual identity.Itrsquos a weird turn of events. It seems women are just on the wrong side of history. But somehow, I donrsquot think theyrsquoll go quietly.

title: Marianne Taylor  Last chance for Mundell to put country before party
story: The majority of these demands are perfunctory, of course, made in the knowledge and expectation that they will be ignored by the target, while playing well with the initiatorrsquos supporters.The craziness of the last few months has precipitated a flurry of genuine and warranted resignation demands, however, which under normal political circumstances would have resulted in multiple ministerial heads rolling in any other era the Prime Minister would have been forced out long ago.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysAnother case in point is Scottish Secretary David Mundell, whose stubborn insistence on being ineffectual in the face of the biggest crisis this country has faced in generations is matched only by that of Jeremy Corbyn. Mr Mundellrsquos wan smiles and empty words about doing the best for Scotland as the Government he is a member of readies itself to push us off the no-deal Brexit clf, is as astonishing as it is appalling. He, too, should have gone months ago, not least over the manner in which his party has arrogantly steamrollered over the views and interests of the country he supposedly represents.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitRemarkably still in post, Mr Mundell now has one last chance to make a meaningful contribution to the ridiculous and dangerous situation the Westminster parliament has created for itself. The SNP is right to call for Mr Mundell to show some mettle and make clear that he will not serve in a Government that is willing to take us out of the European Union without a deal, a situation that would put the already fragile Scottish economy on the road to ruin. As the Scottish Secretary is well aware, businesses will fail, jobs will be lost and real people will suffer the sort of real hardships that will be dficult to recover from.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysSNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford has written to Mr Mundell, laying out the gravity of the situation and calling on him to back growing cross-party demands to halt the Brexit process by extending Article  and making clear to his boss, Theresa May, that he will resign unless she faces up the extremists in her party and takes no-deal off the table.At this critical juncture, the least that the people of Scotland deserve from the man who represents them at Cabinet level is honesty about where his loyalties lie: will he put country or party first  Mr Mundell, it really is that simple.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitOf course, Mr Blackfordrsquos letter also highlights the bleakness of the dilemma facing the SNP. If Mrs May gets her way and Parliament is faced with a last-minute binary choice between her terrible deal - which deprives us of the key benefits being in the EU - and an even more catastrophic no-deal, it leaves the party in a dficult position. How should Nicola Sturgeon instruct her MPs to vote in this scenario  Backing Mrs Mayrsquos ldquomy way or the highway deal would be criticised by many as a U-turn of epic proportions and a sign of weakness. Not voting for it, and thus facilitating a no-deal Brexit, would likely be viewed by many voters as unforgivable, leaving the party open to allegations that this is the outcome it has been secretly hoping for all along, in order to boost support for independence.Ms Sturgeon and her colleagues will be hoping the growing number of Tory ministers and backbench MPs ndash including Cabinet secretaries Amber Rudd, Greg Clarke and David Gauke - poised to revolt against their leader should she refuse to rule out a no-deal Brexit, will come to their rescue in the frantic days and weeks to come.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysThe emergence of the The Independent Groupmay also end up helping the SNPrsquos predicament, at least in the short term. Formed last week when eight MPs resigned from Labour unhappy at Mr Corbynrsquos disastrous leadership, it did not initially appear to be an important development. But when three Tory MPs also resigned and joined up, using the moment to launch a blistering attack on Mrs Mayrsquos disastrous Brexit strategy and their partyrsquos lurch to the right, it started to feel more signicant.What binds these MPs from dferent sides of the House of Commons is dismay at the drt of both parties to the extremities. And despite not being a proper party - yet - or having any actual policiesit seems many voters quite like what they see.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitMomentum has grown over the weekend, with polls already putting the group on  per cent, just one behind the increasingly irrelevant Lib Dems.Many are asking whether TIG has a future. Surely, however, whatrsquos most important is the future of the country, andthis new movement serves only to facilitate the halting of Article , so that a new road out of the current mess can be found, then it will already have done more for the UK than Mr Corbyn. Or indeed Mr Mundell for that matter.

title: the-scottish-universities-struggling-to-make-ends-meet
story: Universities Scotland said new statistics for  showed real terms cuts of up to . per cent for some.Universities facing a real terms cut of two per cent or more include Aberdeen, Abertay Dundee,Dundee,Edinburgh Napier, Heriot-Watt, UHI,Queen Margaret University,St Andrews and Strathclyde.Read more: Universities issue Budget warningThe warning comes after the Scottish Funding Councilpublished details of budget allocations for all universities.The move follows the Scottish Governmentbudget in December where it emerged the sector faced areal terms cut of . per cent.Professor Andrea Nolan, convener of Universities Scotland, said: "These funding allocations throw a stark light on the challenging budget outcome for universities."Every university faces a real terms cut and half of institutions are facing real term cuts of two per cent or more.ldquoUniversity funding has already been cut by pound. millionin real terms since   and the sectorrsquos pension bill alone is set to increase by poundma year."Some institutions are likely to struggle to make ends meet, eroding their capacity to deliver fully for Scotlandrsquos success."Ms Nolan urged the Scottish Government to give more cash to universities to help mitigate "acute financial pressures".Read more: John Swinney dismisses university funding fearsShe added: "We urge it to do so and we urge the Scottish Funding Council to talk to the sector about how they allocate that funding.Mary Senior, UCU Scotland official, said the cuts would have damaging consequences for students and staff an already uncertain time.She said: "If we want a world-leading university system, that is also accessible to students from hard to reach backgrounds, it needs to be properly funded and not hit by further real-terms cuts at a time when other costs are increasing.A Scottish Government spokesman said there were always annual iations for inidual institutions, but there had been no cash reduction as a whole, with more than pound billion invested every year since  .Education Secretary John Swinney has previously highlighted the ability of universities to raise money for themselves with only  per cent of overall funding coming from the public purse.Karen Watt, chief executive of the SFC added: "Against a backdrop of increasing funding pressures, we are continuing to invest in learning and teaching and research excellence."We are also committed to ensuring that our students have the right support to allow them to fulfil their potential at the institutions we fund.

title: when-normal-is-not-normal
story: Organised football violence, source concede, is nothing like the bad old days of the s and s.Late last year Bernie Higgins, the assistant chief constable in charge of policing Scottish games, told The Herald that half of Scotlandrsquos  senior clubs had what he called ldquorisk supporters. Some clubs - and he did not name them - have up to  of such fans.The Scottish Police Federation, which represents the forcersquos rank and file, was even blunter. Its vice chair, David Hamilton, said Scotland ldquohad a resurgence of old problems.Legislation - widely criticised - to deal with sectarianism and hooliganism has been repealed. This, rightly or wrongly, suggest some sources has emboldened problematic elements of Scotlandrsquos football clubs.:Police warns of rising sectarian attacks on officers at Scottish footballEnter Will Kerr, the national forcersquos new deputy chief constable. The Northern Irishman crossed The Sheuch to Scotland in September after decades policing his home turf. He knows about sectarianism. And yet, he told a meeting of his ruling board, he was surprised by what he had seen at Scottish grounds.Will Kerr when still in Northern IrelandSpeaking at a meeting of the Scottish Police Authority in Greenock, he said: ldquoThe vast majority of fans who go to these football matches do so entirely peacefully and just want to enjoy the wonderful spectacle that is Scottish football.ldquoBut what Irsquove been surprised at over the last six months, particularly when it comes to behaviour at football matches, has been two things.ldquoOne has been that level of sectarianism on display and I say that having policed in Northern Ireland for nearly  years.ldquoIrsquove been surprised at how much it is seen as normal... It feels almost visceral in a way I havenrsquot experienced for quite a while.Mr Kerr added: ldquoIrsquove also been surprised just at the level of disorder on display at the some of the football matches and we have been concerned, particularly over the last  months, that there has been a rise in both disorder, that type of offensive behaviour and the levels of aggression to police officers.ldquoWersquove had officers pulled off horses, spat at, attacked - very aggressive behaviour towards them.ldquoWe had a police horse which had pyrotechnic flare thrown at it a couple of weeks ago and was injured to the extent it had to go to the vet.ldquoAgain, Irsquove been surprised that the consistently thuggish behaviour of a very small number of fans is considered normal. This is not normal. It is a sport.ldquoOn both fronts there is a responsibility and a need for everybody, including the police service, to collectively challenge ourselves about how much thatrsquos considered normal and what we can actually do to address it.:Scottish football needs strict liability - heres why we wont get itMr Kerr admitted it was hard to measure the rise in aggression. His remarks, he explained were based on feelings of officers policing the matches.The issue, he said, should not be left to the police. Mr Kerr said clubs, fans, and councils all need to look at what can be done dferently to change this behaviour ldquofrom being normal to being unacceptable.He said part of that will be enforcement but ldquowersquore certainly not going to arrest our way out of this.Scotland is getting outside help. An independent review of policing at football matches in Scotland is due to be launched next week.The sport, meanwhile, is resisting calls for strict liability, when clubs could be punished for the behaviour of their fans. Anti-sectarianism campaigners favour that response.Dave Scott, director of Nil by Mouth, said: ldquoWe canrsquot ignore the loud and angry minority that seem to revel in this behaviour and feel the laws of the land donrsquot apply once they buy a match ticket.ldquoThis problem is compounded by the total lack of action by clubs and governing bodies being allowed to repeatedly bury their heads in the sand on this issue.Other solutions  Liberal Democrats Thursday mooted closing the stands of clubs plagued by trouble.

title: nicola-sturgeon-set-to-call-for-power-to-hold-indyref2
story: With the UKstill mired in negotiating a way through Brexit, sources claim there is an expectation at Westminster that the First Minister will soon request a section  order, granting the Scottish Parliament the right to hold another referendum.But it is widely expected that the answer would be no, with a member of the UK Government telling the BBC: ldquoThere is no answer to this, other than now is not the time.Some commentators believe Ms Sturgeon may even be expecting a firm rejection from Downing Street to stir the pot.But a national broadcaster has reported that, based on internal polling for the Conservatives, opposition to another referendum is hardening and one minister said: "Once youve hit the iceberg, youre all on it together.In response, Ms Sturgeon tweeted: ldquoThe justication here from a UK Minister for trying to block Scotlandrsquos right to choose independence is quite something - lsquoonce youve hit the iceberg, youre all on it togetherrsquo."Well, actually, no, Scotland does not have to sink with the Brexit ship.Ms Sturgeon indicated in January that details of the timetable for a second referendum would be revealed within ldquoweeks.Opposition leaders were quick to attack the prospect of a second independence referendum.Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie said: ldquoThere is no mandate for another isive independence referendum. The SNP failed to win a majority at the last election and the Greens have failed to deliver their million signatures they said would be required before another referendum should be sanctioned.ldquoIn any case, why would we compound the chaos of Brexit with the chaos of independence. Breaking up a  year old partnership is proving to be a disaster, breaking up the  year old UK would be so much worse.ldquoWe all need to focus on stopping Brexit, not breaking up the UK.The last occasion the Prime Minister knocked back a call for a second referendum was in  when she used similar wording then, saying: ldquoNow is not the time.The BBC further reported, though, that senior figures in the SNP may use an election to force the issue, saying itis "pretty obvious what well campaign on andsuggesting such a vote would largely be about the right to hold a referendum.Scotland - where  per centvoted to stay in the EU - voted by % to remain in the UK in the referendum of September , which was billed as a ldquoonce in a generation event.But Ms Sturgeon has been open about her intention to have a second referendum because "Scotland is being dragged out of the EU against its will.Earlier this month, one of Ms Sturgeonrsquos closet advisors said she should offer the softest possible form of independence in order to win over voters.Andrew Wilson, who chaired the SNPs Growth Commission, said: "In the parlance of Brexit, we offer the softest of possible changes to the current arrangements, not the hardest. We recognise the level of integration and all the ties that have bound us for centuries. We create a  that can uny a majority for progress that stands a chance of winning and winning big."The comments infuriated many within the wider Yes movement keen to have another referendum as soon as possible - SNP MP Angus MacNeil, former MP George Kerevan and former SNP leader Alex Salmond have all argued for using the chaos over Brexit to press for a second referendum, but debate continues within the party on the timing of another vote.Responding to the latest reports, an SNP spokesman said: "The Toriesrsquo arrogance is exceeded only by their incompetence."The fact is that the future of Scotland will be decided by the Scottish people not by Theresa May who, letrsquos be frank, is fast becoming a parody of herself."The last couple of years are littered with examples of the PM taking lsquocast ironrsquo positions that later crumbled to dust. Just a matter of days ago she was adamant she wouldnrsquot countenance a delay to Brexit - until suddenly she did."

title: pupils-buy-a-brick-plan-to-raise-cash-and-save-old-kirk
story: The  Days to Save Coats Memorial campaign has teamed up with pupils from Castlehead High School to launch the project they hope could raise up to pound, for their cause.Built in the Gothic revival, the Thomas Coats Memorial Church has been part of Paisleyrsquos skyline since its construction in  ndash and with its striking ft crown steeple, is sometimes referred to as the ldquoexclamation mark on the townrsquos horizon.Its features also include a vaulted ceiling, mosaics, stencilled decorations and carved marble font and pulpit, while a rare , pipe organ, designed by Lincolnshire organ builder William Hill  Sons, has remained unaltered since it was installed in .But the building is now empty and disused.On February , a group of local campaigners launched the  Days effort, aiming to make Coats Memorial a venue to stand comparison with the likes of Glasgowrsquos Oran Mor and Edinburghrsquos Mansfield Traquair, while preserving its history.The steering group is aiming to raise pound. million in  days for its preservation andto use as a multi-purpose venuehosting theatre, opera, ballet, pantomimes, rock concerts, folk music, weddings and other s.They have now announced the ldquoBuy a Brick initiative which will see students from the school lend their time and skills to create  engraved plaques which will be available to the public to buy for poundeach.The plaques will be mounted on the entrance wall within the church building where they will stay, commemorating the many people who donated their time and money to save it.Ian Henderson, a Coats Memorial Steering Group member, said: ldquoI am proud to be in a position to work with the students from Castlehead High School on this campaign. Coats Memorial is a church that was created to enhance our community.Thousands of people have passed through its doors to celebrate lersquos biggest events and we hope it can continue to serve as community space for everyone to enjoy.The campaign has already raised more than pound, in just  days and the ldquoBuy a Brick project is one of many initiatives that the Steering Group has planned in order to make the fundraising goal a reality.Thomas Coats and his family have longstanding links with Paisley. The philanthropist and founder of JP Coats, the cotton thread and zip and fastener manufacturing firm which is intrinsically linked with the history of the town, at one stage employed , people.The entrepreneur ran his thread works in Ferguslie and he and his we raised  children in Ferguslie House. He had been involved in the restoration of Paisley Abbey and funded other projects in the town.
